description.text:
This is a magnetic stir plate based on a 120mm fan, powered by 12 volts. I wanted something larger and more stable than the 80mm units. It uses a PWM speed controller from ebay, either with or without an LCD. At high speed it will throw the magnet, but that's much faster than the speed needed for a vortex to reach the bottom of the 2L vessel. With the 1.5" stir bar, the speed needed to keep a good vortex is well below 50%. It should work fine for larger vessels, given the rather large stir bar. I have only tested it with a 2000ml flask. So far it hasn't thrown the stir bar, unless I really crank the speed far beyond what's needed.

The magnets are N52 1/2" X 3/4". Go big or go home!
http://www.ebay.com/itm/321817266647?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The magnets are quite strong. Handle them carefully! They will shatter if they slam together. The poles are on the flat ends. Alternate the poles when you press them into the MagnetMount. One side of the magnet will have a red dot. Make sure the one has the dot facing up and the other has the dot facing down.

1.5" stir bar
http://www.ebay.com/itm/181806493210?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

120mm fan w/HBD bearings
http://amzn.to/2kkzL8R

PWM speed controller (print the NoLCDSideCar.stl)
http://www.ebay.com/itm/351460554697?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

PWM speed controller with LCD (print the LCDSideCar). Not sure why I used this over the regular PWM controller, other than I like things that light up and change when I turn a knob. If you use this controller, you will have to break the tabs off the side of the LCD module. It should be a tight fit, but a little glue might be needed.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/112061036280?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The side cars are bolted on with 1" #4 screws. They have cutouts for nuts, but the screws are tight enough where they probably aren't needed.

The 120mm fan is bolted to the base using 4 2" #8-32 machine screws. The screws are attached to the base first using 2 nuts for each screw. It needs the spacing from the 2 nuts. Three nuts hold the magnets a bit too far from the base. Test fitting the fan with the mag mount attached, adding washers until the mag mount stops touching the base, than add another washer. I ended up using 2 washers. Add a nut or two to keep the fan in place. There should be enough room for 2 nuts at the end of the screw.
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-8-32-x-2-in-Phillips-Flat-Head-Machine-Screws-4-Pack-28471/202706132

Both sidecars have slots for Anderson Powerpole connectors. I have a ton of these and have ready access to 12V power served up through a fused distribution block (ham radio). I used a 2mm screw to "pin" the connector inside the side car housing. Don't have to use these connectors of course. Make sure whatever you use is safe from vibration and is properly fused.
https://powerwerx.com/anderson-powerpole-connectors-15amp-bonded

The MagMountBase is super glued to the top of the fan. The fan hub is curved, with a matching curve in the printed base. This must be as well centered as possible. Use a slow drying glue to give you enough time to properly center it. The magnets are pressed into the MagnetMount, with alternating poles on the same side. The MagnetMount should slide onto the top of the MagMountBase. A little knife scraping may be necessary to fit them together without force. Either use a 3mm x 10mm screw to permanently keep them together or just use super glue. I created 2 parts in case I needed to alter the spacing of the magnets or change to different magnets without having to re-glue it to the fan. The 4 #8 screws actually support the entire stir plate, with the screw ends resting on the table. A non-skid mat will keep it from moving around, especially if the MagMountBase isn't well centered on the fan.

I modeled this in Fusion 360. The source files as well as IGES are included.

I printed it in PETG since that's what was in the printer. Infill was 30% with 3 solid layers.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

I made these separate so I could more easily experiment with different magnets and different spacings.  The MagMountBase.stl can be modified to fit a different fan, like one that is flat rather than curved.  The picture with the magnets includes both pieces fitted together.

description.text:
I recently acquired a ETX-90 with a computer controlled mount. I had some problems withe the DEC clutch slipping and like everyone else broke the knurled nut loose on the clutch peg.

This is my take on a repair for this model of mount. I had the modify the arm by removing the existing peg and drilling out the center to allow the 3d printed peg to insert. There is a captured nut in the print to mate up with the clutch knob. I have not found the need to have to glue this repair in, it works just fine in place.

author: Fearchar

description.text: A spring-loaded bearing idler for 1.75mm filament. It should be compatible with the Makerbot mk7 and the Makerbot mk7 Drive Gear, but I designed it for a spur gear from SDP-SI: S10T05M020S0505. It has clearance on the bearing side so you can print a mirrored idler and use it in a dual extrusion setup. The overhead lever design was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15718 . That design has no filament guide which is required with a spur gear. The idler bearing also seems to contact at slightly the wrong position when I printed it. The body was insprired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13727 which I quite like except for the fact that it protrudes on the idler side preventing use with dual extrusion. I also find that the force required can flex the lower part of the base because of the slight bounciness of the spur gear. The hinge on that design is also superior to mine but I did not see a good way to incorporate it in my design.

After about a year the pivot arm on my original print has flexed enough to require a larger spring.  I've printed a replacement at 100% infill but not converted yet.  I'd recommend at least 40% infill when printing this.
Parts required:
2x M3x18 flat head screws.  These secure the base and the arm to the stepper.
1x M3x10 flat head screw to hold the bearing.
1x R2 (US size) or 623 (Metric) bearing
1x fairly strong spring.
Instructions:
Print one plate normally for single extrusion.  Mirror and print again for dual extrusion.
Remove the builtin support from the curve that meets the stepper, from the idler where the bearing goes and from the hole where the bearing screw goes.  You may need to run a 2mm drill through the filament guide or clean out the other holes, depending on your printer.
Tap the bottom side of the bearing screw for M3 and secure the bearing.
Mount the base to the stepper with the leftmost screw.  Pinch a strong spring between the base and the arm while securing the right side screw.  You can also try to insert the spring afterwards.

title: Fostex TH series slider repair part

description.text:
On the Foxtex TH-series headphones (TH-X00, TH-600, TH-900, E-MU Teak, Denon AH-D2000, D5000, D7000), the headband is attached to the slider (see reference photo) by an extremely shallow M2 screw, 2mm total if my measurements are accurate. Half the length is spent interfacing with the actual headband.

On a pair I was repairing, the screw hole stripped out and I was unable to repair it with JB Weld or Epoxy; there simply isn't enough material there to adhere to.

Enter the repair part. This part hooks under the bottom of the screw holes that hold the cover to the slider and gives you an M2 hole that you can use in conjunction with a screw and nut. My recommendation is to assemble screw->metal headband->repair part->nut, place the part in position and push down, then put the cover into place and screw in. You may need to trim part of the cover out, there is a ledge 90 degrees between the screw holes. I had already trimmed mine testing a previous version. This ledge is integral in supporting the headband - I didn't know this before I cut mine out. You can get most of the support back by playing around with the assembly order and using longer screws or a standoff.

My recommendation would be to have a box of assorted M2 fasteners available before embarking on this project. I used a 120pc Hilitchi that I got from Amazon.

If you improve on this design, or adapt it into repairing something else please share back with the community as well. Fostex headphones are difficult to repair and there aren't a lot of repair parts available.

description.text:
I thoroughly enjoy a boardgame called Elder Signs. It is a game in which you have to complete tasks in rooms of a museum to gain Elder Signs to prevent awakening a Boss Monster. While completing these tasks, your Sanity and Stamina are at risk. Sanity and Stamina are essentially your health in the game. When you lose Sanity or Stamina, you have to remove the amount of lost Sanity or Stamina tokens off of your players card. The problem is, the tokens are TINY and a pain in the butt. This game has a bunch of different types of tokens, cards, dice etc. that it's also easy to lose track of which tokens are which.

I've created this counter to hopefully remedy some of the issues that I have with an otherwise wonderful game. I created this counter in what I think is the proper style to the game. For each counter you will need to print 1 Base, 2 Caps, 2 Keys, and 2 Spinners. I printed the Base and Caps in Hatchbox Wood PLA and the Keys and Spinners in Hatchbox Bronze PLA.

Inspiration for this counter came from a couple sources:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090368 and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547881

After printing, clean all strings, bumps and any other imperfections with files, knives sandpaper etc.

TEST FIT ALL PIECES
I was lucky enough that my Caps would snap into my Base with a little pressure. Some of my Keys were a little loose in my Spinners, some were a little tight.

Sand the inner surface of the Base to help with smoother rotation of the spinner.

Place Caps on Base and stain (if desired). Putting the Caps on the Base will help to minimize the stain from getting on the surfaces that we will be gluing.

Paint the numbers. The colors for Sanity is blue and Stamina is red. Also, they appear on the character's card with blue on the left and red on the right.

Next you will glue the Key into the Spinner.
**IMPORTANT*****
Make sure before you glue the Key into the Spinner that you put it THROUGH the Cap FIRST.

Make sure the bottom of the Key sits flush to the bottom of the Spinner and does not protrude. Try not to glue the Key or the Spinner to the Cap. The Key should rotate freely through the Cap.

Last, carefully put glue on the inner lip of the Base. Place the Spinner/Key/Cap assembly onto the Base. Try to make sure that the Window of the Cap is facing forward.

Try not to glue the Spinner to the Base. The Key should rotate freely through the Cap.

A divider thing to put inside a glass that you use to hold things.

Divide a glass into multiple segments to keep the toothbrushes from fighting, or keep your pencils organised, or whatever.
Select the size of the glass, the number of segments, the wall thickness, and chamfer if you want for the inside edge of the glass.
If you want a chamfer it is printed on the top of the print so there is no overhang.

Measure the inside diameter of your glass. If it tapers then you need to use the smallest diameter or convince me to make a tapered option.
Decide what clearance you want between the divider and the glass. If the glass is perfectly round this will make it all ok. I use 0.3.
Decide how many segments you want to divide your glass into.
Decide what wall thickness you want. I use 2.
Decide how tall you want the divider. It doesnt have to come up to the top of the glass, or it can go past the top of the glass if you want.
Decide if you want a chamfer. The bottom inside edge of the glass is rounded. You can add a chamfer to make the divide sit on the floor of the glass, or you can let it sit on the rounded corner. I think it looks better sitting flat on the bottom so i use a chamfer but i cant make your decisions for you.
If you do go with a chamfer (as you should) then you can decide how big you want the chamfer. The size is the height and width of the chamfer. The chamfer is put on the top of the divider so you are printing it upside down. That means that there is no overhang.

description.text:
Another remix of my ever evolving previous remixes for 80/20 brand 1010 and 1020 size Extruded Aluminum T-slot. This is a potential adjustable foot for the 90 1/4" tapped holes that i designed for my custom 3d printer / CNC mill (now "Personal Food Computer" project). description.text:
Since I started using my low friction Universal Spool Holder published here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1614533 once in a while, when extruder rapidly pulls the filament, several convolutions of the filament become loose. They then overlap each other and eventually may block the filament flow. This causes print to fail.
The solution ended-up being very simple. I used old 608 bearing as a ballast which hangs on the filament. Initially I simply hung it on a paper clip, but then decided to design and print this thing that holds the bearing and has a hook that will fit both - 3mm and 1.75mm filaments.
When using with Vertex K8400 printer, this ballast brings another benefit - filament entry angle into the extruder is not as steep as the original, especially with the smaller pool sizes.

This thing is designed to assist build plate levelling for the CreatBot DX printer. It may or may not work for printers which use a similar overhead gantry system such as the Ultimaker 2 - it depends upon the critical measurement of gantry components.

In order to use this design the user will need to provide 2x dial indicators:

https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01H035DRO

Alternative:

http://www.harborfreight.com/1-inch-sae-metric-digital-indicator-93295.html

Note: These dial indicators can be ridiculously expensive. However we aren't interested in superior accuracy so the target price for a compatible indicator should be circa $30 US.

You also need 2x M6 flanged rivnuts OR 2x M6 nuts (depending on which STL file you print - you don't need both) and 2x M6 x 40mm bolts plus washers. Optionally, should you wish to couple the main jig with other components you will need a number of M3 flanged rivuts and M3 bolts/washers. The rivnuts slide into holes designed into this thing.

You can apparently modify these dial indicators so that readings can be taken by external equipment (I haven't tried this):

https://hackaday.io/project/511-digital-dial-indicator-cnc-surface-probe

The basic principle for this thing is to level the heated bed so that it is parallel to the overhead gantry axes. I use the Y axis shaft to mount this jig this, however as the Y axis is coupled to the X axis shaft the alignment does take into consideration both axes.

You don't actually need the 'secure' component of this thing - I have provided it in case you want to clamp the thing onto the Y axis.

Aligning the heated build plate is super easy, and I find much more accurate (and quicker) than moving the gantry to each corner of the build plate and then sliding a piece of paper under the nozzle. Herewith the procedure:

1) Set the nozzle-to-build-plate distance for one single point centrally placed in the middle of the build plate. The actual physical position does not need great accuracy - it just needs to be roughly central.

POWER DOWN THE PRINTER (You don't want the printer moving the gantry system if you accidentapply hit the home switch - trust me, you probably will).

2) Install this jig onto the Y shaft. The two (rear) ears of this jig should slide alongside the red nozzle component of the CreatBot DX, and the jig firmly pushed against the red component. You could use double-sided sticky tape to hold it in position - I didn't bother.

3) Move each of the dial indicators over the point set in step 1, and zero each dial indicator. This defines the vertical height measured by the dial indicator - we need to set the build plate height to be the same across the whole build plate.

4) Move the gantry to centre-front. The left and right dial indicators show the inclation of the left/right front corners of the build plate. Use the thumbscrews under the build plate to set zero on the respective indicator. These adjustments mean that the respective corner of the build plate is at the same height as the central point defined in step 1.

5) Repeat for the rear corners by sliding the jig/gantry to the rear.

You probably won't set these corner heights to be exactly zero - I found +/- 10 micrometres to be acceptable for levelling purposes.

This simple process should result in your build plate being at the right height across its entire surface. Quick, easy and repeatable.

title: E3D dual head on Velleman VERTEX K8400 Air Intake

description.text:
I recently discovered a problem with my E3D dual head mount for Vertex K8400 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1687914
The fan I used generates such a strong airflow that the hot end is not able to heat above 223 degrees. This makes it impossible to print with ABS.

One of the solutions would be to replace 12.5 Ohms resistor, but I decided to take a different approach and design a duct with removable inserts changing airflow. The duct replaces insert.stl file of the original design.

air_flow_valve_opening.stl file is the one I use to allow hot-end to heat up above 245 degrees. I am also sharing .123dx file that will allow you to modify the sizes of openings, if needed.

Firmware changes will not have effect because the fan has to be directly connected to the power supply. I tried connecting it to the plug of the original fan but very soon ended up with clogged nozzle. If your read about E3D - everybody says the fan should be "always on".
Replacing 12.5 Ohms resistor with 15 or 18 Ohm would have the same effect and the fan would work quieter. I just decided to take 3d printed approach in this case, but may eventually replace the resistor.

description.text: My first 3d modelled object, a simple cog connector, useful for printing out for jewellery, key chain, or something to tinker with. If you do use this, please show me what you did with it so I can see how well it's useful! Has yet to be printed so not sure how it will go.
miniature T16

I designed this end cap to add support in my kitchen's lazy susan. I used a 30cm long aluminum rod with a 10mm diameter and printed two caps for either side. The inner diameter of this cap is 10.925mm, the outer "foot" is 40mm. Very simple STL that should be easy to edit and print for all kinds of sizes and projects.  
I put a channel in the bottom of the foot for glue if desired. It doesn't affect the model (though it does seem to improve printing).
Just print it - it's very simple. There's a channel at the bottom of the print to apply a bead of glue, if desired.

author: Entropy4U

description.text:
I just recently purchased a 1000mw laser engraver which has a max engraving area of 38x38mm (pre-assembled with DVD drive internals and came with software).

This amount of engraving area is perfect for set of four standard playing dice.

Just print this jig and rubberband it (in two places) to the bed, plop the dice and and go. [Well you might want to measure your bed & dice and edit the OpenSCAD file to generate a new STL custom to your exact needs. This jig works for the blank dice that I personally have.. your's may be a different size.]

EDIT: Added some photos. First one shows what my dice look like after printing and wiping black powder off with a wet rag. Then I brush on thinned down acrylic paint in wild sloppy fashion. After dry I rub them down on a very flat cotton disk cloth on a flat surface.. takes off all the paint except what's within the laser engraved recess. [Sometimes it is helpful to very slightly dampen the perfectly flat cloth with a couple drops of water -- helps take off the excess dry acrylic paint.] See the following thread if interested:

https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1671419/paint-filled-dice-100-laser-engraver

comments.text: thanks for posting this, I used the basic idea to create a holder for my dice in a homebuilt laser engraver (converted from an old 3D printer).

description.text:
This Raspberry Pi 3 NES case...

  • Is visually as close as possible to a real NES
  • Fits a Raspberry Pi 3
  • Has plenty of space in the case for additional parts
  • Is made in OpenSCAD and customizable
  • Is easily assembled and disassembled without screws (exception: the Pi itself is screwed to the bottom section of the case)
  • Provides simple access to all ports
  • Can be printed and assembled very easily (arguably, this one is a slight miss :-)

Please watch this video showing tips for printing, and how to assemble the pieces:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PS3_iR2NpAU

Picking a Version: Vents

There are two versions of the vents on the top part.

  • Square vents are closer to how the original NES looked, but a bit harder to print, since the height of the first layer needs to be perfect for the model's details to be visible
  • Rounded vents are easier to print, and look a bit more modern

See the "round vs square" image to see the difference.

Picking a Version: Raspberry Pi Orientation

There are three different versions of this case's top and bottom parts.

  • If you need access to all ports, and want to be able to quickly replace the MicroSD card, print the "upside down pi" versions of the top and bottom parts.
  • If you want a cleaner version of the case without the the ports in the back, print the versions of the top and bottom parts without "upside down pi" in their name; this version doesn't provide access to the MicroSD card, the ethernet port, and two of the USB ports, but the back looks a bit prettier.
  • If you want the cleanest possible case, go with the "sideways" versions of the top and bottom parts. These move HDMI, audio, and power to the back, and don't expose the SD card, Ethernet, or USB ports (although there is room inside the case to plug something into the USB ports).

If you're unsure, print the "upside down pi" versions of the top and bottom parts.

Screws

The Raspberry Pi uses M2.5 screw holes on its PCB. However, I've used M3 screws to screw the Pi in place. The reason for this is that the screws are threaded into printed plastic, so it's not possible to torque them tightly. By screwing M3 screws into the PCB's M2.5 screw holes, the screws hold the Pi in place perfectly, even if the screws aren't torqued into the printed plastic.

Having said that, you might not want to do this, since there is a chance that you might harm your Pi by screwing M3 screws into its M2.5 holes. Therefore, there's a variable in the OpenSCAD file where you can change the screw diameter the case uses. If you want to use M2.5 screws, open the OpenSCAD file, change the screw_size variable to the value you want, and render the bottom part of the case.

Customizer

Unfortunately, the Thingiverse Customizer seems to be unable to render this OpenSCAD file. Therefore, to customize it, download nespi.scad and open it in OpenSCAD. This will allow you to change the text on the lid, and make some other changes to the model.

Small Build Plate

If your printer has a small build plate, and the model is too wide to fit on it, you can download the OpenSCAD file. There's a width parameter inside the file that's not visible in the Customizer. However, after you've changed the width, the inserts of the feet may overlap with the black ribbons. You can either not use feet, or just glue the feet on slightly offset, instead of inside the inserts.

Working Buttons and LED

By default, this model doesn't have working buttons, or a working LED. However, ElTacoLoco created a button and LED holder that allows you to make the LED and the buttons functional. Check it out here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2011955

USB Ports in Front

If you want USB ports in front of the device, where the original NES had controller ports, check out this remix:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2811744

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 Micron

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print all of the STLs with individual models once, except for the feet (four times) and the buttons (twice).

Print without support; the model has built-in supports that can be removed after printing. If you don't have a good part cooling fan, the built-in supports may fuse with the printed part; in this case, edit the OpenSCAD file to remove the built-in supports, or increase the margin between the supports and the printed parts.

I printed with 15% infill, 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers, 3 shells.

When printing the top part, make sure that the width of the first layer is such that you don't end up with slits between the air vents. You can do that by changing the layer width on the first layer, or changing the number of shells.

If you want your final print to look like a real NES, print each part using the color indicated in its name. For the light gray, I used E3D light gray Edge, which was the best fit for the NES's color I could find. For the dark gray, any average gray PLA should do fine.

The feet should be printed with flexible filament.

You need all of the printed parts, four M3 screws, a Pi 3, glue, and a screwdriver. Start by carefully breaking away the built-in supports for the top and bottom parts. Note that the support pieces on the top part will actually fuse with the printed part; this is intentional, and is required in order to allow the printer to bridge the inset section. To remove the fused parts, first carefully pull the long part like in the picture, either downward or forward Next, use a pair of pliers to carefully pull off the smaller part. Be gentle so as not to break the printed part. Glue the feet into the bottom part's feet inserts. Push them in all the way using a screwdriver. glue the two buttons and the red LED to the bottom part (unless you want to use the buttons for something, in which case, don't glue them in :-). Screw the Pi into the case. Note that this picture shows the non-upside-down version, which is most likely not what you want. For the upside-down version, flip the Pi upside-down so that the USB ports go in the back, and the SD card goes in the front. Carefully push the top part onto the case. Again, in your case, you'll probably see the SD card through the slot, not the USB ports. Slot the lid's left nub into the hole (we'll secure it properly in the next steps). The two black ribbon pieces are not the same; find the one that has part of its insert cut off. The one with the cut-off insert goes in the front. Slot it in at the bottom first, then at the top. This should secure the lid. Do the same for the ribbon in the back. The lid should now open freely. To disassemble the case, open the lid, and use a screwdriver to pull out the top part of the front ribbon, then use the screwdriver to push out the bottom part from the inside of the case. As an optional last step, paint the text on the lid red.

comments.text: Definitely looks like your print is shifting somehow. Whether it's not adhered to the bed correctly or if you're using glass on your bed it's shifting, etc. Not much else will make a wavy print like that.
comments.author: Boldamoeba

comments.text: Yeah, it doesn't look like the print is shifting on the bed. I think that would likely produce a less regular pattern. The layers seem to shift in one direction (either x or y, depending on how the part is placed on the bed, but not both). They also don't seem to shift by clear increments, so it's probably not the belt shifting (then you'd see increments of belt notches), and it's probably not the stepper motors (then you'd see degrees of stepper motor increments). To me, it looks like something else is shifting.
comments.author: djdizzy28

comments.text: Ok. I figured it out. For some reason, when I place the model anywhere in cura. It prints at the home location no matter what (need to figure out how to change that) but it was hitting the boundary of my print area and pushed the layers over. Thanks again for everyone's advice. :)
comments.author: LKM

comments.text: Ah, that's why it's shifting so smoothly! It's literally using microstepping to shift... That's a new one, I have to keep that in mind if I see something similar in the future! Congrats on figuring it out!

comments.text: Basically, this happens because the printed plastic shrinks when it cools, so which deforms the printed model, and pulls the printed layers up. There are many different parameters that affect this, so without knowing more about your printer and the filament you're using, it's impossible to say.

comments.text: Looking at the picture you've posted, there seems to be pretty severe underextrusion in some areas of the print. This makes layer adhesion weak, and is what causes the pegs to break off. My initial guess would have been that you have a partially clogged nozzle, but given that you have replaced the nozzle, this is probably not the culprit.

comments.text: I was able to download and print this successfully (thanks!), but your installation instructions say to use M3 hardware. The drawings of the RaspberryPi say 4x M2.5 mounting holes, drilled to 2.75mm+/-0.05. Not sure how you were able to use M3 hardware? I definitely can't thread mine into the board (but it does drop into the printed piece just fine).
comments.author: tldavis

comments.text: You're right, the Raspberry Pi board has M2.5 mounting holes. There's a problem, though: when you're attaching a Pi to a printed part, and use M2.5 screws, you'll have to torque the screws a bit to attach the Pi securely; otherwise, the screws can wiggle in the mounting holes. However, if you try to torque screws on a printed part, you're likely to strip the threads you made in the plastic.
comments.author: tldavis

comments.text: I have this issue as well. My board is 2.5 and the holes are M3. I don't feel modifying the PI holes when I can print a new piece.
comments.author: LKM

comments.text: I've added a variable to the OpenSCAD file where you can change the screw diameter. Change the screw_size variable to the value you want, and render the bottom part of the case.

title: Nextion 3.5" Display Wemos D1 mini ESP8266 case

description.text:
This is a wall hanging case for a Nextion 3,5" LCD touch display combined with a Wemos D1 Mini (ESP8266) board to control it.

The Nextion display gets fixed by 4 small screws (sorry, I do not have any specifications, just grabbed and tried some screws lying around). The Wemos board just gets clipped into the case. The case has openings for connecting a USB cable to the Wemos (programming and power supply) and one for inserting a micro SD card into the Nextion display (for uploading the GUI). The bottom of the case can be mounted by 2 screws to the wall. The top just slides onto it.

There are two areas close to the Wemos which are printed thinner than the rest of the case. I intended to fix two LEDs there to show some important status information (like icy roads warnings). But by now I did not implement this.

I am using this to have an always on display showing me the following information:

  • current time (pulled by ntp)
  • internet based weather conditions and forecast (values, graphics and text)
  • current readings of 4 local temperature/humidity sensors (via my FHEM home control)
  • status of some switches etc, of my FHEM home control

The switches can be touched to change light settings. They also reflect changes done via other means (timers in FHEM, other remote controllers I am using).

In addition to the home screen two more screens can be selected by touching the buttons at the top corners . One screen is showing temperature history of the local sensors of the last 24 hours. The other screen has more home automation controls.

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You need to figure out yourself if your printer can print the openings of the case without supports.

comments.text:
I made a small addition to the code. I was having some issue with the screen not always receiving the values properly, so I added a listen and retransmit:
void valToLCD(String field, int value) {
DEBUG("Updating %s to %i\n",field.c_str(),value);
String command = field + "=" + value;
nexSerial.print(command);
nexSerial.write(0xff);
nexSerial.write(0xff);
nexSerial.write(0xff);
// while(!nexSerial.available());
while(nexSerial.available()){
int endByte = 0;
int incomingByte = nexSerial.read();
if(incomingByte==0x1A){
Serial.print("Failed to update ");Serial.print(field);Serial.print(" code: ");Serial.println(incomingByte, HEX);
valToLCD(field,value);
}
if(incomingByte==0xFF)endByte++;
if(endByte>=2) break;
}
}

comments.text:
Hi ex3meryu,
actually the wiring is so simple that I do not dare to draw it ;-) Please have a look at 6th photo/ the most right one in the list. If you enlarge that one (with the icon in the upper right corner of the image) you will see all the wiring. The Wemos D1 mini gets power by its USB port. The display is connected to ground and +5V of the Wemos to supply it. RX from the display (yellow) goes to pin D5 ("TX" looking from the Wemos side), TX of the display (blue) to D6 (defined as RX). That's it.

comments.text: What make and model of 3D printer are you using?  These have been printed hundreds of times by different printers and users and only a few people report problems.  I'm curious what you are using and what your print settings are.  Thanks

comments.text: I loaded the model into slic3r and i had the same Problem with the bride. Then pressed split in Slic3r and had 2 Models. Now it was fine.
comments.author: Mr_MegaTronic

comments.text: I am printing now at 0.1mm layer height but the problem is that the feather tips are about 1mm AWAY from the body and I'm printing without supports so the printer tries to drop plastic in mid air which means a blob of olastic lands somewhere else. I'm surprised no one else has mention this.
comments.author: pcarlson

comments.text: What model of printer are you using?  0.1 mm  layer height is pretty aggressive for many printers and many designs have features that overhang by only a little.  It is pretty well understood that 0.1 mm is pushing it for most filament type printers and not all designs can handle it.
comments.author: pcarlson

comments.text: I'm using a Flashforge Dreamer. I can print down to 0.05mm without much of a problem and 0.1mm seems to work fine. But when I slice the model, the bottom of the feather tips are actually lower than the rest of the feather so that means the printer will try and put a drop of plastic in mid air. But these blobs were super easy to remove from the model, a slight touch with a stanly knife and a shot from a lighter cleaned it up in a flash.
comments.author: Mr_MegaTronic

comments.text: To follow-up on my post below: I fixed the "inside-out" owl problem and did a successful test print using MakerWare and an MBot Cube 2. I posted the updated STL files at the following link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:132938http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... If you are using MakerWare, download that STL file.
comments.author: etotheipi

comments.text: For those with MakerWare issues: the right owl has inverted normals -- they're all facing inwards.  So each "outer" surface of the female owl is interpretted as an interior surface.  This is why it shows up weird in MakerWare (it's displaying the interior of an object), and it doesn't print properly, because it's not sure what to do.
comments.author: etotheipi

comments.text: nettfab (http://cloud.netfabb.com/)http://cloud.netfabb.com/) will fix the problem! :-)

description.text:
Don't you wish, sometimes, that you could just hang your lightsaber on the wall the way it should be in a time of peace?
All you need is the Empire not searching for troubles, and a pair of nicely and precisely designed hooks.
Well, I can't do much about the Empire thing (for that, you'll need real Jedi knights and a lot of, uh… "aggressive negotiations"), but I can help for the hanging part with these hooks specially designed, that will fit perfectly all sorts of lightsabers.
In case you're a short and green-skinned Jedi master, there's even the special Yoda-sized ones, so that your weapon too on the wall can be hanged. :)
Enjoy, and may the Force be with you!

comments.author: jasondwhitman

comments.text: The alignment is automatic.  There is no provision to mask portions of subsequent scans to prevent inclusion in the subsequent fusion.  That feature would be great, as it would allow for placement of the object on a pedestal to fix shadowing in the Z-axis.  I would imagine that these sorts of features might be added in future software updates, but that is pure conjecture.  There is no eraser feature yet, either.  It is still a huge improvement, but there is a long way to go.
comments.author: RolfKarlstad

comments.text:
Oops, I forgot to remove the "extra hand" which was created due to a deflection of the arm while I laid it on its side.
Things like this sort of reveal the remaining flaws in the software... an ability to discriminate between objects which should be added and those which there is no basis for should be available! Essentially everything is additive, there is no easy way to get errant scans to disappear!
comments.author: RolfKarlstad

comments.text: Nice scan, but how do you align scans? In Artec Studio (Handscanners) you can manually align scans and edit them. You have erasers to delete unwanted objects before alignment.

title: Double stepper extruder with hot end

description.text:
This double stepper motor extruder is not designed for the "No, No'rs" of this world. It's designed for having a cheap and ultra light strong extruder with hot end in place to minimize the dynamics when hooked up in a Delta printer or Robot Arm.
The two 28BYJ mini steppers are original unipolar steppers. Be aware that I have modified these steppers to bipolar. For instruction please follow this link. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ROFjf_7IrRA
The body is designed as an elastic hinge in order to eliminate as much as possible parts.
Each stepper carries his own extruder wheel; in that way two motors are pulling the filament.
The total weight of the extruder plus hot end including FAN is 202 grams.
I strongly advice to start with reading my instructions considering them as "lessons learned".
Please build one by your own and make it a better one and then please share.

Printer:

Dlta printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

nGEN material used

comments.text: Thank you.  I am looking for a very lightweight direct extruder for replacement on a Mini Fabrikator. Print speed on the printer is pretty low so this may work.  I will give it a go.  My understanding is that some of these motors do have metal gears but the part numbers overlap so finding the metal ones are difficult.
comments.author: GDC

comments.text: Let me know if you need step files or some other  CAD format.
comments.author: GDC

comments.text:
A light extruder on the top end of my robot arm was the goal.
The extruder needed to be with the nozzle otherwise I would have outside forces working on the robot arm.
I wanted the use the principe of elastic hinges in order to reduce the amount of parts to the minimum. As you can see, only one part is a make, the rest is standard.
I had it working on my Robot arm (See other THINGS of my) but at slow speed, like 30 - 40 mm/sec. Faster would make no sense because the robot arm is not stable enough for 3d printing. Not sure if it would print much faster or if, than it would maybe not last that long because of the Nylon gears of the reductor. The principe works fine. Two motors pulling at the same time on the filament creates enough force to get it through the nozzle. (PLA at 114 dgr C) I keep on looking if the same kind of steppers would come with metal gears inside; if so, I will build another one.
Please take extreme care of alignment, it's important for make it all to work.
comments.author: evandene

comments.text: How well does it work?
comments.author: GDC

comments.text:
A light extruder on the top end of my robot arm was the goal.
The extruder needed to be with the nozzle otherwise I would have outside forces working on the robot arm.
I wanted the use the principe of elastic hinges in order to reduce the amount of parts to the minimum. As you can see, only one part is a make, the rest is standard.
I had it working on my Robot arm (See other THINGS of my) but at slow speed, like 30 - 40 mm/sec. Faster would make no sense because the robot arm is not stable enough for 3d printing. Not sure if it would print much faster or if, than it would maybe not last that long because of the Nylon gears of the reductor. The principe works fine. Two motors pulling at the same time on the filament creates enough force to get it through the nozzle. Please take extreme care of alignment, it's important for make it all to work.

Notes:

You can print this hollow. Brim is recommended. Because it's small it's a good idea to print two at the same time.

Remove brim and support material (if printed with support). Solder a resistor close to the LED and put the wires through the small holes, bend them back up and optionally glue it in place. If you have some space between the socket and the insert plastic, you can even add a rectifier (so polarity doesn't matter anymore) and/or a capacitor (anti-flickering) to it. The possibilities are endless!
If you don't use a rectifier and your LED doesn't light up after installing it, try to rotate it 180 degrees. That way the polarity changes and it should light up.
Basically I took a socket that was already installed and measured everything like the lenght and diameters, designed it and printed it. That's it.

comments.text: Can you write here or in the description which resistor and capacitor you used?
comments.author: alesr

comments.text: Basically it depends on what LED you want to put into the socket. Every LED has a specified forward voltage and current (check the LED's datasheet for details). Just use a resistor of around 150-300 ohms. The smaller the resistor the brighter the LED.
comments.author: alesr

title: Magnetic Polyhedral Dice Holder / Tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is another d20 magnetic dice holder. I made the lid to hold the dice when on the table. The magnet holes are for 6mm diameter / 3mm length disc type magnets, although the lid fits pretty tight if you dont want to use them. Enjoy..... And if someone knows how to turn this into a "customizer" thing, for changing the diameter of the magnet hole on the fly, please let me know.

The files with "25in" in the names were designed with a little thicker top that fits more loosely, and is sized for the 6-pack of .25in neodymium magnets that you can buy at Michael's...but they are kinda steep @ 6 for $4.95. Needed them quick though.

I have printed in various PLA prints in .1mm to .3mm layer heights. Printing with carbon fiber PLA makes the visible outside layers almost completely blend together; with no sanding or finishing required.

***** Make sure you check the polarity of the magnets before placing them into the holes...I did not learn from experience.

Somebody make it, and post a pic. or else.

title: Filament Roller IR Sensor Version 2

description.text:
A Kickstarter campaign for this product is live:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/522476987/filament-roller
Make a donation and receive a finished Filament Roller. Thanks for your support~

This is a prototype IR sensor and alarm which detects the direction and speed of your filament spool. This sensor will sound an alarm when your spool stops due to filament-jamming, nozzle-clogging, extruder-grinding, motor-stalling, or out-of-filament.

This second version is a stronger and easier-to-build version. However it has larger parts that can only be printed on larger 3D printers. Without the PCB, you can use this item like a regular low-friction filament roller. This roller can hold spools that are 5-12cm in width.

Required parts:
608 ball bearings (4 ea)
M3 x 12mm screws (14 ea)
M3 x 18mm screws (2 ea)
M3 nuts (16 ea)
M3 x 30mm screws (4 ea)
M5 washers (4 ea)
M5 nuts (4 ea)

Optional parts:
Filament Roller control board (1 ea)
Small rubber bands (16 ea)
Large rubber bands (4 ea)

Base(2-piece)-12x16cm (2 ea) AND Base(2-piece)-Connector
OR

These settings are just suggestions. This is a functional print and aesthetics are not a primary concern.

Base Assembly

If your printer is large enough to print a single 22x16cm base, then print it and no other assembly is required.

If you are printing a 2-piece base, then make 2 prints of the 12x16cm base. Print 2 base connectors and use M3 screws and nuts to secure the 2 halves of the base together.

PCB Pylon

If you have a Filament Roller PCB, then print:
1 Pylon(PCB),
1 PCB spacer,
1 Pylon footer.
Using an 18mm M3 screw, attach the elements in the following order:
PCB pylon - PCB - PCB spacer - Base - Pylon footer - M3 nuts

Regular Pylon (no PCB)

For the other pylons, print 3 copies of:
1 Pylon (no-PCB),
1 pylon footer.
Using a 12mm M3 screw, attach the elements in the following order:
Pylon - Base - Pylon footer - M3 nuts

Roller

Print 4 rollers.

If you are using a Filament Roller PCB, then you must paint at least one of them in order to block IR light.

Spray paint, house paint, car paint, etc can all block IR light.

After painting your roller(s), insert the 608 bearing using steady pressure.

Attach the roller onto the pylon using an M5 screw, washer, and nut.

If you have rubber bands, attach them to the roller to make a "tire" surface.

Spool Tensioner

In order to smooth out the feeding of the spool, insert the tensioner through the hub of the filament spool.

Attach rubber bands from the spool to the M5 bolts on the pylons. This adds light tension to mitigate the "spring" force of the filament.

comments.text: Only one board on one corner is required. Each board has two sensors to make an encoder which can read direction as well as speed. comments.text: Hi Malcom, i understand what you mean, but if you merge the screw and the the cup, you need to change the cup design, since it has to be flat to stick onto the bed avoiding internal supports. I suggest to past the parts with bicomponent epoxy glue, it will be strong enough and will never break or, if you made it in ABS, melt few ABS with acetone and use this as glue. description.text:
A subtle remix of dirtsky's elegant OUYA case, this design adds grooves along the bottom of the case to allow ventilation. I also added a variant of the case top without the "OUYA" text for a more minimalistic look.

Depending on your OUYA device rev, the cooling fan screw heads may sit a bit proud and interfere, but a quick targeted sanding to ease those areas in the lid made it fit.

Don't judge the waviness of the print - my printer needs new bearings and some realignment. And I was printing impatiently fast. :) But a first attempt at a mid-print filament swap worked out very well.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select / Wanhao i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in eSUN black PLA and MakeShaper cool gray PLA/PHA (manual color swap at layer 20 inserted into gcode using Simplify3D).

Add supports to the back panel cutout unless you're a wizard at bridging. All the chamfers and vents otherwise should print without issue.

description.text:
It's a top-mount spool holder for the Robo3D.  
It mounts at the top of the case, using the filament slot.  
Print parts "right, left, middle.stl" and choose if you want the plain spool holder top part or the one with two holes for hanging your most used tools(tweezres/spatula..?)  
Push towards either end of the slot until it sits firmly.  
Have been using it for weeks and even though I have taken it apart and reassembled it numerous times, still functions reliably.

remixed_from.author: Rejutka
remixed_from.title: "Universal" jigsaw piece, connects with itself on every side

title: Interlocking scrabble/jigsaw/puzzle tile (two directions only), empty faced

description.text:
This is a redesign/rethink of my previous attempt of an interlocking scrabble tile.
The previous "universal" design, was able to connect on all four sides - but for scrabble you really don't need more than two, all letters have to face the same direction.

Since there are clearly defined male and female connectors, it's easier to connect them - just slide the male under the female and it'll push it upwards and connect.

The downside is that the connection isn't as strong, and you probably can't pick up the whole plate without it crumbling.

Rotating the set still won't be a problem, though, and I think that is worth a lot.

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

doesn't much matter :-)

Infill:

dunno, a bit?

Notes:

The tiles you see in the picture have been printed with a .6 nozzle and .3 layer height - I suppose a bit lower height might be better for smooth connecting, but so far (testing with 4 tiles) it works fine.

Slighty better than the first attempt, much better than the original :-)

You may have noticed that I re-set this to WIP for a while.
I decided to slightly alter the connectors again.

Now the tip of the male is a tiny bit lower than the lip of the female, so it can be pushed under without having to lift the second tile. It will be pushed upwards later, of course.

Also, I made the male a bit longer, to have more grip on the female sides - that way it doesn't wobble so much.

There are two versions in here - the one with holes is so you can easily drop a fitting plate (15x15mm) on it and don't have to worry about the whole set getting too high.
The one without holes has about 1mm above the holes, so you can either cut down carefully, or simply glue on some letters.

Tinkercad link

https://tinkercad.com/things/jQrcp8uzYnI

Use this for easy duplicating/manipulating of the tile.

text = Chris Swartz

title: Tevo tarantula Z alignment and support mod

description.text:
This is my bracket design with adjustable bearing supports to help align the leadscrew and also to remove the load of the Z coupling improving the Z movement.

The bottom bearing support uses one thrust bearing (10x18x5.5) and a printed collar. These will hold the weight and remove the load from the coupling.
There are 2 lower brackets. One with base and other without base. I had to design both because most people use the brackets from Robcad with base. I use modified Robcad's brackets with no base so that the entire printer structure is flat on a wooden base.

The top bracket is untested. It also has an adjustable (radial) bearing support to help align the leadscrew. If the lower bracket is used, then the collar for the upper bracket is not needed.

These designs are based on the work created by Jim Marks (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1676571).

Before printing, rotate the parts in your slicer so that they lay correctly.
These designs are under test so any suggestion or modification are welcome.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

75%

title: STACK-A-LACK
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The STACK-A-LACK is an adapter to stack IKEA LACK tables on top of each other. No screwing, no glueing, just stacking. It wasn't designed to be very sturdy, but it should keep the top table from sliding off.

There is also the DOUBLESTACK-A-LACK connector that can be used to combine two LACK stacks.

If you want to stack two LACKs, print the STACK-A-LACK plate.
If you want to rack two stacks (four LACKs), print the RACK-A-STACK-A-LACK plate if your bed is large enough, or both the STACK-A-LACK and the DOUBLESTACK-A-LACK plates.

The RACK-A-STACK-A-LACK plate contains the adapters for all four corner and the two middle connectors.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Considering how thin the walls are, it doesn't really matter how much infill you use. I'm printing them solid, just to get a bit more strength and a nicer outer perimeter. My shell thickness is set to 1,2mm, and that's also how thick the walls are.

Assembly
  • Slide a STACK-A-LACK over each leg of the upper table, with the closed square at the top and the half square at the bottom and on the outside of the leg.
  • Place the upper table on the lower table and make sure that the STACK-A-LACK slides over the top of the lower table.
  • Enjoy your LACK stack.

comments.text: How do you install these?  Can you post a picture of the lacks with them attached?  Thanks!
comments.author: jeremysouthard

comments.text:
You just put them on the corner of the lower LACK table, with the two extended walls going over the corner, and then put the legs of the upper table into the square that's now sitting on each corner. The Things shown in the renders are are oriented upside down, for printing.
The Things with two squares are supposed to be used if you want to stack multiple tables next to each other, so they each span two corners of each table.
